{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Ioan Alecu (I. A.) Bassarabescu | image = I A Bassarabescu.jpg | imagesize = 240px | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_date = {{birth date|1870|12|17}} | birth_place = [[Giurgiu]], [[Kingdom of Romania]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1952|3|27|1870|12|17}} | death_place = [[Ploiești]], [[Communist Romania]] | occupation = schoolteacher, civil servant, politician | nationality = Romanian | period = 1889–1943 | genre = [[sketch story]], [[farce]], [[novella]], [[memoir]], [[parody]] | subject = | movement = [[Literary realism]], ''[[Junimea]]'' | signature = | website = }}
'''Ioan Alecu Bassarabescu''' (commonly rendered '''I. A. Bassarabescu'''; December 17, 1870 - March 27, 1952) was a Romanian comedic writer, civil servant and politician, who served one term (1926-1927) in the [[Senate of Romania]]. His work, mainly in prose form, is remembered as an accomplished and noteworthy contribution to [[Romanian literature]], capturing the dreary life of provincial clerks in the early 20th century. Not interested in producing a singular novel, like his mentor [[Gustave Flaubert]], he concentrated instead on the [[sketch story]] genre.
In his debut stage, Bassarabescu belonged to ''[[Junimea]]'', the mainly literary and politically conservative club. He was friends with [[Titu Maiorescu]], ''Junimea'' leader, and with the ''Junimist'' author [[Ioan Alexandru Brătescu-Voinești]] (with whom he is often compared). Married into a political family, Bassarabescu had joined the [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880–1918)|Conservative Party]] by 1906, and, although still mainly active as a teacher, received high appointments in the bureaucracy.
During [[World War I]], Bassarabescu he supported the [[Central Powers]] and was even appointed [[Prefect (Romania)|Prefect]] of [[Prahova County]] under a [[German Empire|German]]-led occupation. This put his political career on hold until 1925, when he joined the [[People's Party (interwar Romania)|People's Party]]. Moving into [[right-wing populism]] in the 1930s, Bassarabescu had stints in the [[National Agrarian Party (Romania)|National Agrarian Party]] and the [[National Christian Party]], and joined the official [[National Renaissance Front]] in 1939. His last years were spent in seclusion: losing his fortune to [[Bombing of Romania in World War II|Allied carpet bombing]], stripped of his [[Romanian Academy]] membership by the [[Communist Romania|communist regime]], he died suddenly in a road accident.
==Biography==
===Early life and debut=== Bassarabescu descended from ''[[boyar]]'' families that occupied court positions in [[Wallachia]]: his father, Alecu, was a ''[[Pitar (rank)|pitar]]''; his mother, Elisa, was the daughter of a ''[[Starosta|staroste]]'', relatives with General [[Romulus Boteanu]].<ref name="gc581">Călinescu, p.581</ref> Alecu had received a [[progressive education]] at the [[Saint Sava Academy]]; his colleagues there later instigated the [[Wallachian Revolution of 1848|1848 Revolution in Wallachia]].<ref>Călinescu, p.581; Eftimiu, p.462</ref> Although he had settled in the [[Danube]] port of [[Giurgiu]], his own family was more closely associated with [[Bucharest]], the national capital. Noted members of this branch include Nicolae "Nae" Bassarabescu, who worked as a journalist in the [[Liberalism and radicalism in Romania|liberal-radical]] press,<ref>Eftimiu, p.462</ref> later setting up the first [[newsstand]] chain in town, and composer George Bassarabescu.<ref>{{ro icon}} Mihai Sorin Rădulescu, [http://www.viataromaneasca.eu/arhiva/58_viata-romaneasca-3-4-2009/10_cronica-literara/311_bucurestii-doctorului-vatamanu.html "Bucureștii doctorului Vătămanu"], in ''[[Viața Românească]]'', Nr. 3-4/2009</ref>
One of the couple's seven children,<ref name="gc581"/> Ioan Alecu was born in Giurgiu, an [[Romanians|ethnic Romanian]] baptized into the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]].<ref name="luca">{{ro icon}} Vasile Pop-Luca, [http://astra.iasi.roedu.net/texte/nr34z7.html "Arhiva ''Revistei Române''. Fondul N. I. Herescu"], in ''Revista Română'' ([[Asociația Transilvană pentru Literatura Română și Cultura Poporului Român|ASTRA]]), Nr. 4/2003</ref> In 1877, the family left the city because of [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] bombardments during the [[Romanian War of Independence]], settling in Bucharest.<ref name="vladu">{{ro icon}} Bogdan Vladu, [http://adevarul.ro/locale/giurgiu/giurgiu-masoneria-ioan-a-bassarabescu-vicepresedintele-marelui-orient-romaniei-mihail-daia-autorul-imnului-masonic-1_527b4087c7b855ff56c83145/index.html "Giurgiu și masoneria"], in ''[[Adevărul]]'' Giurgiu edition, November 7, 2013</ref> The eight-year-old Bassarabescu was first enlisted at school in Bucharest's Yellow Ward, and later in the Green Ward.<ref name="gc581"/>
Enrolled at [[Saint Sava National College]], Bassarabescu was classmates with various intellectual luminaries and political figures of his generation, among them [[Constantin Banu]], [[Ion Livescu]] and [[Scarlat Orăscu]].<ref>Livescu, p.7, 299-300</ref> Influenced by their teacher, classical scholar [[Anghel Demetriescu]], they formed their own literary club, which held its meetings in the Saint Sava basement.<ref>Livescu, p.7, 300. See also Eftimiu, p.463</ref> Together, they put out the makeshift literary review ''Armonia'', described by an aging Bassarabescu as [[Polygraph (duplicating device)|polygraphed]] "with the faintest and least readable violet letters to have ever been used for writing in this world."<ref>Livescu, p.299-300</ref> It was soon replaced by a less makeshift periodical, the bi-monthly ''Studentul Român''. Bassarabescu published his first short stories in that paper, and then in the youth review ''Generația Viitoare'', before being hosted (with words of praise and encouragement) by the literary supplement of ''[[Românul]]'' newspaper.<ref>Eftimiu, p.463</ref>
''Studentul Român'' only put out three issues, closing down due to a "lack of funds", but not, as Bassarabescu quipped, to a "lack of scientific and literary contributions".<ref>Livescu, p.300</ref> By this time, the Saint Sava pupils began attending literary- and social-themed conferences at the [[Romanian Atheneum]]. It was there that Bassarabescu met the successful writer [[Alexandru Vlahuță]], who gave him some of his first literary pointers.<ref name="pvh270">[[Petre Haneș]], "Fapte și comentarii. I. A. Bassarabescu despre Al. Vlahuță", in ''Preocupări Literare'', Nr. 5/1942, p.270</ref> Soon, Bassarabescu's pieces were hosted by ''Revista Nouă'', a literary journal managed by [[Bogdan Petriceicu Hasdeu]] (1893).<ref>Călinescu, p.581; Eftimiu, p.463</ref> This was an impressive feat, to judge by Bassarabescu's own words: "imposingly grand" and "too expensive" venture, ''Revista Nouă'' had fascinated him and his Saint Sava colleagues.<ref name="pvh270"/> He also dabbled in [[Parody|parodic]] poetry, some of which was published by the [[Symbolist movement in Romania|Symbolist]] review, ''[[Literatorul]]''.<ref name="gc581"/>
By 1896, after such permutations, Bassarabescu was firmly affiliated with ''Junimea'', contributing to the ''Junimist'' tribune, ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', and cultivating a friendship with its founder, [[Titu Maiorescu]].<ref name="lb(10)165">Boia (2010), p.165</ref> Like his generational colleague [[Ioan Alexandru Brătescu-Voinești]], Bassarabescu joined in just as the ''Convorbiri Literare'', for long disregarded by Maiorescu, was entering its decline stage. As noted by literary historian [[Zigu Ornea]], the stories of Bassarabescu and Brătescu-Voinești were a rare diversion, the magazine having grown "monotonous", "suffocated by bulky specialized studies".<ref>Ornea, p.113, 120</ref> Bassarabescu was not dissuaded by such problems: he would contribute to the magazine throughout most of his life.<ref name="lb(10)165"/> He managed to impress a wide range of professionals, from the ''Junimist'' novelist [[Duiliu Zamfirescu]] (who guessed in him a future "great writer") to the independent [[Ilarie Chendi]].<ref>Eftimiu, p.463-464</ref>
Between his move from ''Revista Nouă'' to ''Junimea'', Bassarabescu had enlisted at the Literature and Philosophy Faculty of the [[University of Bucharest]] (graduated 1897), while also working as a [[Ministry of Public Finance (Romania)|Finance Ministry]] clerk.<ref name="gc581"/> At around that time, he had moved to [[Ploiești]] city, Prahova, where he would live for most of his life, and became a teacher of geography and French. Various sources have it that his relocation occurred in 1896<ref name="vladu"/> or 1897,<ref name="lb(10)165"/> but, according to literary historian [[George Călinescu]], Bassarabescu had spent 1898 working as a substitute teacher in [[Focșani]].<ref name="gc581"/> Around that moment, his work appeared in the review ''Noutatea'', put out in [[Iași]] by Berman Goldner-Giordano.<ref name="vdpseudo">{{ro icon}} Victor Durnea, [http://www.romlit.ro/pseudonimele_lui_g._ibrileanu_colaborator_la_noutatea_iai_1897 "Pseudonimele lui G. Ibrăileanu. Colaborator la ''Noutatea'' (Iași, 1897)"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 11/2008</ref>
===Political and literary rise=== [[File:Casa în care a locuit scriitorul I. A. Bassarabescu, Str. Ștefan cel Mare nr. 10, Ploiești.JPG|thumb|350px|Temelie Dinescu and Bassarabescu's residence in [[Ploiești]]]] In January 1900, with the start of a new ''Convorbiri Literare'' series, Bassarabescu was co-opted onto the journal's editorial committee, overseen by geographer [[Grigore Antipa]].<ref>Ornea, p.119-120</ref> According to Ornea, the panel membership evidenced in itself that political ''Junimism'' had mutated into eclecticism: Antipa was a [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal]], and one regular member, [[Dimitrie Voinov]], a [[Socialism|socialist]].<ref>Ornea, p.120</ref> Like other ''Convorbiri Literare'' contributors, Bassarabescu saw his work published in the more radical right-wing ''[[Sămănătorul]]'' magazine, but he did not necessarily identify with the ''Sămănătorul'' agenda.<ref>Călinescu, p.601. See also Lovinescu, p.201</ref> He was invited to publish there by his mentor Vlahuță, who rewarded his contribution with an original canvas by painter [[Nicolae Grigorescu]].<ref name="pvh270"/> In 1903, he answered a similar call from Livescu, publishing in the new magazine ''Revista Teatrelor''.<ref>Livescu, p.34</ref>
Politically, he leaned toward the mainstream [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880–1918)|Conservative Party]], which had Maiorescu as chief doctrinaire. It is probable that Bassarabescu began frequenting the Ploiești Conservative chapter in or around 1901, making friends with political boss Temelie Dinescu, and courting his intellectual daughter, Ecaterina Dinescu.<ref>{{ro icon}} Paul D. Popescu, [http://www.ziarulprahova.ro/stiri/cultura/82320/femei-prahovene-de-azi-de-ieri-si-mai-demult "Femei prahovene de azi, de ieri și mai de demult – Ecaterina Bassarabescu (I)"], in ''Ziarul Prahova'', December 14, 2010</ref> From about 1906,<ref name="luca"/> he registered formally with the Conservative Party.
In April 1904, Bassarabescu married Ecaterina Dinescu. The modest ceremony was compensated by a sizable dowry (including a family home on R. Stanian Street) and a honeymoon in [[Venice]].<ref name="pdpecat2">{{ro icon}} Paul D. Popescu, [http://www.ziarulprahova.ro/stiri/cultura/82761/femei-prahovene-de-azi-de-ieri-si-mai-de-demult "Femei prahovene de azi, de ieri și mai de demult – Ecaterina Bassarabescu (II)"], in ''Ziarul Prahova'', December 21, 2010</ref> Temelie Dinescu died just four months after the event, leaving them ownership of another home, located on a street that was named in his honor.<ref name="pdpecat2"/> Some time after, Ecaterina gave birth to a daughter, Maria-Elisabeta (whom both parents nicknamed ''Cireșica'', "Little Cherry").<ref name="pdpecat2"/>
The first bound collection of Bassarabescu's [[novella]]s and stories was released (as ''Nuvele'') in 1903, with [[Editura Socec]]. In 1907, [[Editura Minerva]] and ''Biblioteca pentru toți'' published two other selections, ''Vulturii'' ("The Eagles") and ''Norocul'' ("Luck").<ref name="gc1007">Călinescu, p.1007</ref> With [[Mihail Sadoveanu]], [[A. de Herz]], [[Emil Gârleanu]], [[George Ranetti]] and some others, he was employed by the [[National Theater Bucharest]] to work on professional translations of comedy and drama. As Livescu recounts, this was a project heralded by manager [[Pompiliu Eliade]], who had recently been "appalled" by the poor-quality translations already in circulation.<ref>Livescu, p.93-94</ref> Bassarabescu was assigned to work on comedies by [[Georges Courteline]], and, Livescu argues, did an "excellent" job.<ref>Livescu, p.111, 144</ref> In 1908, Socec published his adaptation of a 15th-century [[farce]], ''[[La Farce de maître Pierre Pathelin|Master Pierre Pathelin]]'' (as ''Ovidiu Șicană'').<ref name="gc1007"/> His wife also wrote poetry and prose, published in reviews such as ''[[Luceafărul (magazine)|Luceafărul]]'', ''[[Convorbiri Critice]]'' or ''[[Epoca (Romania)|Epoca]]'', usually under the pen name of ''Irena Mohor''.<ref name="pdpecat2"/>
During those years, the Bassarabescu family played host to a long succession of writers visiting Ploiești.<ref name="pdpecat2"/> Bassarabescu became rather close friends with two senior figures on the cultural scene: the Ploiești literary theorist [[Constantin Dobrogeanu-Gherea]] and satirist [[Ion Luca Caragiale]].<ref name="vef464">Eftimiu, p.464</ref> In March 1908, Bassarabescu affiliated with the prototype [[Romanian Writers' Society]], and was elected a member of its steering committee.<ref>{{ro icon}} Teodor Vârgolici, [http://www.romlit.ro/centenarul_societii_scriitorilor_romni "Centenarul Societății Scriitorilor Români"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 15/2008</ref> As such, he had a say in the scandal during which the Society, which was Christian-only, moved to reprimand a [[History of the Jews in Romania|Jewish Romanian]] writer, Eugen Porn, and was in turn accused of [[antisemitism]]. Bassarabescu took a partisan position, acknowledging that some of Porn's concerns were valid, but concluding that Porn was rather the [[Anti-Romanian discrimination|anti-Romanian]].<ref>Victor Durnea, [http://www.revistatransilvania.ro/arhiva/2006/pdf/numarul5-6/p54-64.pdf "Primii pași ai Societății Scriitorilor Români (IV). 'Afacerea Porn' (continuare)"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320015859/http://www.revistatransilvania.ro/arhiva/2006/pdf/numarul5-6/p54-64.pdf |date=2012-03-20 }}, in ''Transilvania'', Nr. 5-6/2006, p.56</ref>
A [[Freemasonry in Romania|Freemason]], he was proposed for membership in the [[Romanian Academy]] by Duiliu Zamfirescu and seconded by Maiorescu, themselves Freemasons.<ref name="vladu"/> He was elected a corresponding member on March 25, 1909.<ref name="luca"/> Also in 1909, Socec published another selection of his writings, ''Noi și vechi'' ("New Ones and Old Ones").<ref name="gc1007"/> Some two years later, Bassarabescu received high appointment in the [[Ministry of National Education (Romania)|Education Ministry]], as Inspector for the Arts for Minister [[Constantin C. Arion]].<ref name="gc581"/><ref name="luca"/> In 1912, he was commissioned as Inspector-General for Education.<ref name="luca"/>
===Germanophile and Prefect=== The onset of [[World War I]] marked a turn in Bassarabescu's life. During Romania's neutrality years (1914-1916), he adapted himself to the [[Germanophile]] sentiments of his ''Junimist'' and Conservative peers. He gave lectures at the Bucharest Conservative Club, on topics such as ''[[Realpolitik]]'' and the [[British Empire]].<ref name="lb(10)165"/> He also joined ''Junimea'' geographer [[Simion Mehedinți]] in putting out ''Dumineca Poporului'' review, but contributed his trademark satirical pieces, rather than political articles.<ref name="lb(10)165"/> Such works were grouped in the 1916 volume ''Nenea'' ("Old Chap"), published with [[Editura Librăriei Leon Alcaly|Alcaly]].<ref name="gc1007"/>
Eventually, [[Ferdinand I of Romania]] declared war on [[Austria-Hungary]], the [[German Empire]] and the other [[Central Powers]]. It came as a shock for the Germanophiles. Although subject to the [[Romanian Army]] draft, Bassarabescu managed to avoid being called into [[active duty]], and was instead appointed captain of a [[military reserve]] in [[Mogoșoaia]] train station.<ref name="lb(10)165"/> Through their personal contacts, both Mehedinți and Maiorescu tried to get Bassarabescu appointed to an even safer position, at a [[postal censorship]] bureau.<ref name="lb(10)165"/>
In the second half of 1916, the Central Powers broke through Romania's line of defenses, forcing the government and the Army to withdraw northeast, into [[Moldavia]]; Bucharest was abandoned. In these circumstances, Bassarabescu checked himself into a Bucharest hospital, claiming that he suffered from a "severe cold". This allowed him to stay in German-occupied territory, and, in the Romanian loyalist ranks, labeled him a probable [[deserter]].<ref name="lb(10)166">Boia (2010), p.166</ref> As historian [[Lucian Boia]] notes, the suspicion is still standing: an entry in Maiorescu's diary shows that Bassarabescu had left the hospital on at least one occasion during the interval of his supposed illness.<ref name="lb(10)166"/>
In the wake of the [[Battle of Bucharest]], Bassarabescu was held in captivity and processed by the [[German Army (German Empire)|German Army]]. [[Alexandru Tzigara-Samurcaș]], a ''Junimist'' in the German ranks, intervened for his release, and then employed him at the Bucharest Police Prefecture — Bassarabescu served there as Divisional Chief from February to April 1917.<ref name="lb(10)166"/> The Germans then forced Bassarabescu back to his adoptive Ploiești and to his schoolteacher's career.<ref name="lb(10)166"/> According to writer [[Victor Eftimiu]], who knew and befriended Bassarabescu, this assignment suited him perfectly: "Himself a shy man [like his characters,] he was content with sticking to his provincial schoolteacher's job."<ref name="vef464"/>
A year later, with [[Treaty of Bucharest (1918)|peace negotiations]] under way between the Central Powers and Romania, Bassarabescu was reintegrated into the civil service by the emergency cabinet of [[Alexandru Marghiloman]], a Germanophile Conservative. On May 7, 1918,<ref name="lb(10)166"/> he was made [[Prefect (Romania)|Prefect]] of [[Prahova County]]. He lasted there for a full nine months, earning respect from the populace and defending its interests in disputes with the German occupiers.<ref name="lb(10)166"/>
The [[First Armistice at Compiègne|Armistice with Germany]] on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] revolutionized Romania's positioning and brought Marghiloman's administration to a standstill. On the very [[Armistice Day|day of the Armistice]], Bassarabescu handed in his resignation.<ref name="lb(10)166"/> The loyalist regime which took over suspended Bassarabescu from his teaching post, and subjected him to a military inquiry. He was eventually cleared, even praised for his efforts as Prefect, and allowed to resume his work in education.<ref>Boia (2010), p.166, 359</ref> He also resumed his literary activity, which resulted in the 1919 volume ''Un dor împlinit'' ("A Satisfied Longing", Steinberg Publishers), followed in 1923 by another Socec edition of ''Nuvele'' and ''Moș Stan'' ("Old Man Stan", [[Editura Cultura Națională]]).<ref name="gc1007"/> In 1923, he joined the Writers' Society literary tour of [[Transylvania]], sharing the stage with [[Eugeniu Botez]], [[Al. T. Stamatiad]], [[Ion Minulescu]] and others.<ref>Mohanu, p.176</ref>
===1918 downfall, 1925 return=== Throughout the war and down to Marghiloman's death, Bassarabescu held on to the presidency of a declining Prahova Conservative chapter.<ref name="luca"/> The whole party, now redesigned into a "Conservative-Progressive" group, was becoming numerically insignificant. According to Bassarabescu's own claim, this was because, in post-war [[Greater Romania]], "mediocrity", "obscurantism" and "fishing in murky waters" had become the standard of political life. Marghiloman, he argued, was a "sailor" in an age that preferred "corsairs".<ref>''Lui Alexandru Marghiloman, omagiu cu prilejul unei îndoite aniversari: prietenii și admiratorii lui'', [[Editura Cultura Națională]], Bucharest, 1924, p.76-78</ref> In the mid-1920s, Bassarabescu himself abandoned the Conservative-Progressives, and made a successful return to national politics. He joined the [[People's Party (interwar Romania)|People's Party]] (PP) of [[Alexandru Averescu]]. In exchange, he was made Vice President of the PP section in Prahova and, following the [[Romanian general election, 1926|June 1926 election]], a [[Senate of Romania|Senator]] for that county.<ref name="luca"/>
In office only until the [[Romanian general election, 1927|1927 recall]],<ref name="luca"/> he worked on the short story selections ''Un om în toată firea'' ("A Fully Grown Man"), published that year with Socec, and ''Domnu Dincă'' ("Mister Dincă"), which came out, in 1928, at Casa Școalelor.<ref name="gc1007"/> Two more small volumes of his works were published in the [[Cartea Românească]] digest: ''Spre Slatina'' ("Onwards to [[Slatina, Romania|Slatina]]"), then ''Pe drezină'' ("On the [[Draisine]]").<ref name="gc1007"/> In 1930, the Grand Orient of Romania elected Bassarabescu one of its [[Masonic Lodge Officers]]—demoted to honorary member in 1933, and affiliated with the regional ''Libertatea'' Lodge in 1937.<ref name="vladu"/> There was also a proposal to make him a full member of the Romanian Academy, where, in 1928, he was giving a formal speech narrating "two epochs in Romanian literature".<ref name="gc1007"/> According to his own recollections, although he passed one round of voting, he was eventually sidelined and another candidate took the seat (1931).<ref name="luca"/>
In 1932, the PP split between a conservative group, headed by Averescu, and a radical one, led by [[Octavian Goga]]. Bassarabescu sided with the latter, leaving the PP to join Goga's [[National Agrarian Party (Romania)|National Agrarian Party]] (PNA).<ref name="luca"/> This was a problematic political move: the PNA was firmly planted on the antisemitic right-wing, albeit its prejudice was mild enough to even allow some Jews into party ranks.<ref>Boia (2012), p.102-103, 308</ref> At the time, his more virulently antisemitic colleague, Brătescu-Voinești, was gathering support for purging the literary world of what he called "abject" Jewish influences.<ref>Boia (2012), p.72-73, 78-83, 107, 148</ref> Bassarabescu occasionally joined in, such as when he cosigned Brătescu's letter to novelist [[Mihail Sadoveanu]], an ambiguous document which implied that Sadoveanu had given in to such Jewish influences.<ref>Boia (2012), p.79</ref>
Three years later, Bassarabescu followed the National Agrarians into their merger with the [[National-Christian Defense League]], and became a member of the resulting [[National Christian Party]] (PNC).<ref name="luca"/> This was a more evidently antisemitic organization, unwelcoming of all Jewish PNA members, and publishing open statements against "the kikes".<ref>Boia (2012), p.70, 102-103, 178, 187, 209</ref> As noted by Bassarabescu himself, he was still a PNC member in May 1938, "upon the chief's [Goga's] death".<ref name="luca"/> His literary work at the time was an [[anthology]] of Romanian literature, edited in collaboration with [[Petre Haneș]] (published 1937).<ref>Călinescu, p.978, 1007</ref> In 1935, ''Convorbiri Literare'', in the process of recovering unknown writings by the late Maiorescu, also published four letters that Maiorescu had sent to Bassarabescu decades before.<ref name="gc1007"/>
===Final years=== Bassarabescu benefited from the rise of an [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] single-party regime during the early month of [[World War II]]. He made a publicized bid to join the [[National Renaissance Front]], and was accepted into its ranks on Christmas Day, 1939.<ref name="luca"/> In 1940, Casa Școalelor put out his ''Opere complete'' ("Complete Works").<ref name="gc1007"/> As a guest of the [[Romanian Atheneum]], Bassarabescu introduced the public to the largely forgotten work of a 19th-century female writer, [[Sofia Cocea]].<ref>Călinescu, p.1007; [[Sanda Golopenția]], "Sofia Cocea", in Katharina M. Wilson (ed.), ''An Encyclopedia of Continental Women Writers, Volume One: A-K'', [[Routledge]], London, 1991, p.259. {{ISBN|0-8240-8547-7}}</ref>
He was by then a highly decorated member of the establishment: a recipient of the [[Order of the Crown (Romania)|Order of the Crown]] (commander), the [[Order of the Star of Romania]] (officer) and the [[Cultural Merit Order]] (officer).<ref name="luca"/> His work focused on recollections from an earlier age, such as a 1942 piece about his youthful encounters with Vlahuță, in ''Gazeta Cărților'', a literary newspaper.<ref name="pvh270"/> In 1943, [[Editura Cugetarea]] put on sale his definitive collection of ''Proză'' ("Prose"),<ref name="gc1007"/> which included some of his memoirs. As Eftimiu notes, they are self-deriding pieces, acknowledging "a mediocre destiny".<ref name="vef464"/>
The Bassarabescu family fortunes turned during the [[Bombing of Romania in World War II|carpet bombing campaign of 1944]]. While the Bassarabescus fled for their safety to nearby [[Slănic]], their Stanian Street lodging was destroyed; they moved to their Dinescu Street residence.<ref name="pdpecat2"/> Upon war's end, Bassarabescu was also targeted for political retaliation. In 1948, the new [[Communist Romania|communist regime]] [[List of purged members of the Romanian Academy|stripped Bassarabescu and 112 others]] of their Academy membership.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Păun Otiman]], [http://www.akademos.asm.md/files/1948_anul%20imensei%20jertfe%20a%20Academiei%20romane.pdf "1948 - Anul imensei jertfe a Academiei Române"], in ''Academica'', Nr. 4 (31), December 2013, p.121</ref>
The same year, Ecaterina Bassarabescu died, leaving Ioan Alecu to be cared for by daughter Maria-Elisabeta. The latter was a career woman, who had graduated law school and was among the first Romanian female judges.<ref name="pdpecat2"/> On March 27, 1952, Bassarabescu himself died, the result of a car accident in Ploiești. Although Călinescu and Eftimiu simply note this is a fact,<ref>Călinescu, p.581; Eftimiu, p.466</ref> later sources describe the circumstances of this accident as generally suspicious.<ref name="vladu"/>
In death, Bassarabescu was recoverable. According to Eftimiu, communism allowed Bassarabescu's work to be published "in tens of thousands of copies", "a circulation that they have never had before."<ref>Eftimiu, p.466</ref> The [[Giurgiu County]] library in his native city bears his name since 1991.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.bjgiurgiu.ro/istoric.htm History] at the I. A. Bassarabescu County Library site</ref>
==Literary work== The chief sources of inspiration behind Bassarabescu's comedic and [[Literary realism|realistic]] style were two ''Junimist'' figures: the Romanian classic [[Ion Luca Caragiale]], and his own friend, Brătescu-Voinești.<ref>Călinescu, p.581, 617; Eftimiu, p.462; Lovinescu, p.202; Mohanu, p.214</ref> In their immediate temporal setting, Brătescu-Voinești and Bassarabescu were both influential on other noted, non-''Junimist'', authors of short prose: [[Emil Gârleanu]] and (for a while) [[Mihail Sadoveanu]].<ref>Călinescu, p.617, 631; Eftimiu, p.462</ref> Beyond this generation, they also influenced the novels or novellas of [[Lucia Mantu]],<ref>Călinescu, p.779</ref> [[Marius Mircu|Marius "G. M. Vlădescu" Mircu]] and [[Cezar Petrescu]].<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p.330, 351</ref>
The eye of such writers is firmly focused on a class of individuals, described for instance in Călinescu: "the isolated folk of provincial boroughs, small-time functionaries of the [[Căile Ferate Române|Romanian Railways]], minuscule bourgeois women grinding the great passions of life."<ref>Călinescu, p.617</ref> Contrary to Brătescu-Voinești, he did not depict such men and women as existential losers or "misfits", but as entirely content with their mediocrity, their "terrestrial ideal": "these people", Călinescu writes, "do not suffer, because they do not aim for, or better said they do not foresee, any existence that would be better than theirs."<ref name="gc581"/> The [[telegraphist]] Domițian, protagonist of ''Vulturi'', identifies perfection with a hefty state pension; Mister Guță, of the eponymous story, will only accept the company of women who share his obsession for [[Nerium|oleander]] flowers.<ref name="gc581"/>
As another distinguishing feature, Bassarabescu replaces Caragiale's sarcasm with a "lyrical", "tenderly grotesque", layer,<ref>Călinescu, p.581-582</ref> while offering "the surprise of a humane bedding" within the provincial soul.<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p.351</ref> His smile, Victor Eftimiu notes, was one "of compassion", his gaze "filtered by tears", like that of a Romanian [[Anton Chekhov]].<ref>Eftimiu, p.462, 464</ref> Literary critic [[Eugen Lovinescu]] finds, in most of Bassarabescu's writings, "the same family atmosphere with its links of solidarity, with all the hardships of finding their daughters husbands, with sisters that will devour each other out of love, with brothers that will carry on their shoulders the maintenance of their entire household". This, Lovinescu believes, was the quintessential "Romanian family" of the urban milieu, with only a lack of "fantasy" and failure at pacing preventing Bassarabescu from producing the great Romanian [[urban fiction|urban novel]].<ref>Lovinescu, p.202</ref> (According to Eftimiu, there is in fact an unpublished Bassarabescu novel, as well as a screenplay.)<ref>Eftimiu, p.462, 466</ref>
Bassarabescu's most lyrical pieces may be characterologic studies of sheer timidity, or other debilitating emotions.<ref>Eftimiu, p.463-465; Lovinescu, p.202</ref> In writing ''Un om în toată firea'', Bassarabescu shared his own experience as a schoolteacher. He found it impossible to fail a grown man trying to pass his primary school exam, even after discovering that he steals notes from his own daughter.<ref>Eftimiu, p.465-465</ref> Elsewhere, a luncheon among family and friends end in collective weeping: people at the table morn their very victim, a long-suffering turkey "with a memorable past".<ref name="gc581"/> This "tenderly grotesque" particularity came through another major influence on Bassarabescu, which distinguishes him among Caragiale's followers: [[Gustave Flaubert]], whose ironic-but-sympathetic accounts of provincial life are at the source of Bassarabescu's "[[Bovarysme|Bovaryistic]] literature".<ref>Călinescu, p.581, 617, 618</ref> Such a melange, Călinescu writes, allowed Bassarabescu to cut "his own profile, with just a minimal literary activity."<ref name="gc582">Călinescu, p.582</ref> In ''Pe drezină'', possibly his most Bovaryistic story,<ref name="gc581"/> the female protagonist dreams of escaping her drab marriage (to an obese [[station master]]), for just a taste of life in the capital. Her ideal of what that life is largely shaped by her one-time visit to Bucharest's [[Gara de Nord]].<ref name="gc581"/>
Several of Bassarabescu's [[sketch story]] works as recognized as tiny masterpieces of the "[[still-life]]" variety.<ref>Călinescu, p.582; Lovinescu, p.201, 202</ref> This means that they suggest a deep layer of meaning just by describing the assortments of a room, or an object apart, without any actual human presence. ''Acasă'' ("Home") is a careful inventory of a room seemingly rented by a partying and womanizing officer, including the half-pleading, half-threatening, letter he receives from his desperate supplier of "colonial goods".<ref name="gc582"/> According to Călinescu, such works may even be paralleled to [[modern art]] in their studied depiction of "urban dreariness". For a relevant case, he cites the sketch story fragment: "At once, through the [[beer garden]] gates, a man showed up carrying with him a giant plank resting on a pole. On this plank, a poster. On the poster, in large handwriting and red paint: 'Gentlemen, today our [[buffet]] is serving you vanilla ice cream'."<ref name="gc582"/>

{{Use Indian English|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} '''[[Pir (Sufism)|Pir]] [[vizier|Wazir]] Ismail Gangji''' / '''[[Vizier|Varas]] Ismail Gangji''' (1788-1883) was an [[Ismailis|Ismaili]] [[Pir (Sufism)|Pir]], religious leader, Ismaili [[missionary]] and social worker from [[Junagadh]],<ref name=a>{{cite book|title=101 Ismaili Heroes: Late 19th Century to Present Age, Volume 1 by Mumtaz Ali Tajddin Sadik Ali|year=2003|pages=209–215|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TlwwAAAAYAAJ&q=ismail+gangji&dq=ismail+gangji&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ByAsUoiPI4yIrAfmyoGgDw&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBA}}</ref> who is also noted for beautiful explanations of some often recited [[Ginans]] of Ismaili faith.<ref name=b>{{cite book|title=Islam in South Asia in Practice edited by Barbara D. Metcalf|year=2009|page=50|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pR0LzVCpfw8C&pg=PA50&dq=Ismail+Gangji&hl=en&sa=X&ei=p8gmUuf1JYj-rAfp6YGwDw&ved=0CE8Q6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=Ismail%20Gangji&f=false}}</ref>
His father Gangji, was a [[Hindu]], who had become follower of Ismaili faith during his lifetime and worked as an employee of ''[[wardrobe|jamdarkhana]]'' department of [[Junagadh State]], where later Ismail Gangji was also employed. Once the wife of the [[Nawab of Junagadh|Nawab]] lost her precious necklace, Ismail Gangji found it and returned to the Nawab. Due to his honesty, he was promoted to a very elevated post in Revenue department and afterwards, he became the head of the departments of the Treasury and Mint in 1821. The Nawab also gave him a piece of land in appreciation of his 50 years services in 1869. He was granted a land in the village of [[Anandpur, Gujarat|Anandpur]], where he built quarters for the destitute.<ref name=a/>
He was an enlightened soul and [[Hasan Ali Shah]], the [[Aga Khan I]] had bestowed upon him title of [[vizier|Wazir]] of Kathiawar elevating him from his post of [[Vizier|Varas]] at a community meeting.<ref name=a/> Later, Varas Ismail Gangji was declared [[Pir (Sufism)|Pir]] after his death by the [[Aga Ali Shah]], when he visited his grave at [[Junagadh]] in 1883.<ref>"Private and Confidential Subjects Discussed" by Religious Study Group of Mombasa, Kenya, 1953-1959, p. 45</ref> During his lifetime, he tried his best to improve the worst conditions of the Ismailis and worked hard to impart knowledge of Ismaili faith, especially in the [[Khoja]] community and served as a missionary converting thousands to his faith. [[Aga Sir Sultan Muhammad Shah|Imam Sultan Muhammad Shah, the Aga Khan III]] is also reported to have said that, "Ismail Gangji converted sixty thousand believers, and taken ten thousand with him."<ref name=a/><ref>Short History of Aga Khan (Bombay, 1903, pp:263)</ref> He was known as the ''Lion of [[Kathiawar]]'' in Ismaili community of Gujarat.<ref name=a/>
Among his notable disciples and converts were Mukhi Virji Kamadia, who shared a close relationship with Wazir Ismail Gangji. Mukhji Virji's son Jamal Meghji was a brilliant orator who became a missionary, and Wazir Ismail Gangji was so impressed with his oratory that he had blessed Jamal Meghji that "Your status will be very high".<ref name=c>101 Ismaili Heroes: Late 19th Century to Present Age, Volume 1 by Mumtaz Ali Tajddin Sadik Ali, 2003: pp 68</ref> Jamal Meghji's son [[Ashad Ali Haji]] (1885-1958), is also counted among one of Ismaili heroes.<ref name=c/>
Ismail died in 1883 after a brief illness and was survived by his sons Kassim and Itmadi Ibrahim both of whom served Junagadh State and were appointed to the post which became vacant upon death of Wazir Ismail Gangji and also served spreading Ismaili faith in Gujarat.<ref name=a/>

'''James Henry Blake''' (October 7, 1808 – August 1, 1874)<ref>Vital Records 267:172</ref> was the City Marshal of [[Boston]] from 1840–1845.<ref>Lane 46</ref> He was the son of Edward Blake and Sarah (Parkman) Blake and nephew of [[John White Webster|Dr. George Parkman]].<ref name="Blake 73">Blake 73</ref> The Parkmans and Blakes were two prominent families of the [[Boston Brahmins]] who were well respected merchants. Blake established himself as a merchant and real estate broker<ref>Boston Directory 28</ref> and also served in the Massachusetts Artillery as Major of Independents Cadets beginning in 1830.<ref>Artillery 437</ref> In 1831, while conducting business aboard the ship ''Mentos'', two pirates boarded the boat where Blake witnessed their arrest.<ref>Salem Gazette 04-26-1831; Volume: IX; Issue: 33; Page: [3]</ref> He testified against the pirates in the first of his many court appearances.
On May 12, 1835, he married Marianne Wildes of Boston<ref name="Blake 73"/> and ran his brokerage on [[State Street (Boston)|State Street]]. He was appointed City Marshal of Boston on May 1, 1840 at an annual salary of $1,000.00.<ref>Police Museum, Lane 46</ref> Blake's term as Marshal was a quiet one and most of his activities involved overseeing July 4 celebrations on the [[Boston Common|Common]],<ref>The Daily Atlas; Date: 07-02-1844; Volume: XIII; Issue: 2; Page: 1</ref> taking a census of buildings,<ref>The Daily Atlas; Date: 11-11-1843; Volume: XII; Issue:114; Page 2</ref> banning illegal hay scales along the wharf,<ref>Boston Evening Transcript, published as Daily Evening Transcript; Date: 12-02-1843; Volume: XIV; Issue: 4098; Page: 3</ref> and clearing the streets of snow.<ref>Boston Evening Transcript, published as Daily Evening Transcript; Date: 12-11-1843; Volume: XIV; Issue: 4105; Page: 3; Boston Evening Transcript, published as Daily Evening Transcript; Date: 12-19-1844; Volume: XV; Issue: 4418; Page: 4 </ref> He also passed a leash law forbidding large dogs to roam the streets.<ref>Boston Evening Transcript, published as Daily Evening Transcript; Date: 02-07-1844; Volume: XV; Issue: 4154; Page: 3 </ref> The most violence he saw was snowball fights, against which he swiftly levied hefty fines.<ref>Boston Evening Transcript, published as Daily Evening Transcript; Date: 12-23-1843; Volume: XIV; Issue: 4116; Page: 3 </ref> For his due diligence, he received a salary increase of $100 in 1844.<ref>Daily Atlas, published as The Daily Atlas; Date: 06-18-1844; Volume: XII; Issue: 300; Page: 2</ref>
Blake was replaced as Marshal by Ira Gibbons in 1845,<ref>Police Museum</ref> and he returned to the more lucrative business of real estate.<ref>Daily Atlas, published as The Boston Daily Atlas; Date: 06-24-1845; Volume: XIII; Issue: 252; Page: 2 </ref> He opened an office on State Street<ref>Daily Atlas, published as The Boston Daily Atlas; Date: 07-26-1845; Volume: XIV; Issue: 22; Page: 3 Daily Atlas, published as The Boston Daily Atlas; Date: 08-04-1845; Volume: XIV; Issue: 29; Page: 1 </ref> and later, as his business grew, moved to Congress Street.<ref>Daily Atlas, published as The Boston Daily Atlas; Date: 12-14-1846; Volume: XV; Issue: 142; Page: 4 </ref> In 1847, Blake, along with police officer Samuel D. Fuller, helped recover articles stolen from Ebenezer Mann, another merchant.<ref>Boston Evening Transcript, published as Daily Evening Transcript; Date: 04-23-1847; Volume: XVIII; Issue: 5135; Page: 2 </ref> Blake and Officer Fuller would meet again under more serious circumstances.
In May 1849, the City of Boston was growing weary of their City Marshal, [[Francis Tukey]], and 17 citizens petitioned to have Blake return to fill the post,<ref>Boston Evening Transcript, published as Daily Evening Transcript; Date: 05-08-1849; Volume: XX; Issue: 5765; Page: 2 </ref> but Tukey held on. Later that year, Tukey was in the unenviable position of coordinating the investigation into the disappearance of Blake's uncle, [[John White Webster|Dr. George Parkman]].
==The Disappearance of Dr. George Parkman== On November 23, 1849, Blake's uncle, [[John White Webster|Dr. George Parkman]], never returned home for lunch. The Parkman family asked the doctor's business manager, Charles M. Kinglsey, to search for him, and James and his brother Edward joined the effort. While Edward went to City Marshal Tukey<ref name="Bemis 46-7">Bemis 46-7</ref> to appeal for police help, James combed the streets of Boston.<ref name="Bemis 167">Bemis 167</ref> Tukey sent police officers to drag the river and search the areas the doctor frequented.<ref name="Bemis 46-7"/> On November 25, James was standing outside the [[Harvard Medical School|Harvard Medical College]], speaking to police officer Trenholm,<ref>Journal 35; Globe 40</ref> when he was approached by one of the professors from the College, [[John White Webster]].<ref>Bemis 146; Stone 94;</ref>[[John White Webster|John Webster]] hurriedly approached him, hand outstretched. He was not wearing a coat, even though the weather required it, and it seemed as if he had just come from the College.<ref>Bemis 167; Stone 94-5</ref> James was confused as he only had a passing acquaintance with the Professor and yet here was Webster holding his hand while explaining he had a meeting with his uncle on the day he went missing.<ref name="Bemis 167"/> He never suspected that he was conversing with the man who would later be hanged for Parkman's murder.<ref>Bemis 167; Stone 94; Journal 28; Globe 40</ref>
After this strange encounter, while still searching, James met William V. Thompson, the City Clerk.<ref name="Bemis 265; Journal 43">Bemis 265; Journal 43</ref> Thompson told James that he had seen his uncle the afternoon of November 23, just after 2:00 p.m.<ref name="Bemis 265; Journal 43"/> He also told him he had spoken to Dr. Webster about George Parkman and Webster told him that Parkman was angry and excited regarding Webster's failure to pay on the outstanding debt to him.<ref>Bemis 265; Journal 42-3; Globe 57</ref> On November 30, 1849, Parkman's remains were found by the College janitor in Dr. Webster's privy. James requested his own Medical Examiner, Dr. Charles T. Jackson, be present to examine the remains.<ref>Bemis 73; Stone 47</ref> There was little doubt they had found his uncle.
James recounted his meeting with Webster in the court trial.<ref>Stone 94-5; Boston Evening Transcript, published as Daily Evening Transcript; Date: 03-26-1850; Volume: XXI; Issue: 6037; Page: 1 </ref> At the end of the twelve-day trial, Webster was found guilty.<ref>Bemis 497; Stone 302; Journal 554; Globe 73</ref> Amid the furor of the verdict, Blake returned to his business.
Blake was involved in other court cases, either as a juror or a plaintiff.<ref>Daily Atlas, published as The Boston Daily Atlas; Date: 05-31-1855; Volume: XXIII; Issue: 283; Page: 2; Farmer's Cabinet, published as The Farmers' Cabinet.; Date: 11-15-1855; Volume: 54; Issue: 15; Page: 2 </ref> Two of his appearances as plaintiff involved the burglary of his clothes.<ref>Boston Evening Transcript, published as Daily Evening Transcript; Date: 07-25-1849; Volume: XX; Issue: 5831; Page: 2; Farmer's Cabinet, published as The Farmers' Cabinet.; Date: 05-09-1860; Volume: 58; Issue: 41; Page: 2</ref> James Henry Blake died on August 1, 1874 in a boating accident in the Boston Harbor.<ref>Boston Journal, published as Boston Morning Journal; Date: 08-03-1874; Volume: XLI; Issue: 13737; Page: 4;</ref>

'''Josephat Torner''' is a Tanzanian [[Albinism|albino]] activist. He has been featured in the documentary "In the Shadow of the Sun".
==Activism== Torner was born in Ngwangwege, near [[Lake Victoria]].<ref name=lm>{{cite web|author=Emile Costard |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2015/03/17/le-combat-de-josephat-torner-pour-la-protection-des-albinos-en-tanzanie_4595118_3212.html |title=Le combat de Josephat Torner pour la protection des albinos en Tanzanie |language=French |publisher=''[[Le Monde]]'' |date=17 March 2015 |accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref> When he was twelve his mother died. Torner then came into contact with a pentecostecal church and followed his secondary education. Torner subsequently moved to Sweden and studied management for three years.<ref name=lm/>
Since 2004 Torner has been an activist for albino rights.<ref name=cnn>{{cite web|author=Teo Kermeliotis and Earl Nurse |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/05/17/world/africa/josephat-torner-albinism-tanzania/ |title='We are killed, we are hunted': Albino activist fights witchcraft murders |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=9 June 2014 |accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://news.vice.com/video/albino-activism-in-tanzania-vice-news-meets-josephat-torner |title=Albino Activism in Tanzania: VICE News Meets Josephat Torner |publisher=[[Vice News]] |date=18 February 2015 |accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref> Torner travels around Tanzania and the world to educate on knowledge of albinism and on [[persecution of people with albinism]].<ref name=cnn/> Torner works for the Ukerewe Albino Association on [[Ukerewe Island]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Jennifer Nkem-Eneanya |url=http://www.konnectafrica.net/josephat-torner-albino-able-and-proud/ |title=Josephat Torner; ‘Albino,’ Able and Proud! |publisher=Konnect Africa |date=20 January 2014 |accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref>
Torner worked together with director Harry Freeland on the documentary "In the Shadow of the Sun." The couple worked together on the project for six years. In the documentary Torner amongst other things confronts a local witchdocter, who are frequently involved in persecution of albinos.<ref name=cnn/> He climbed [[Mount Kilimanjaro]] to attract attention for his cause. He reached the top on 8 August 2011.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.fidadevelopment.fi/?id=410&selArticle=305 |title=Fida’s disability activist climbed Kilimanjaro |publisher=Fida |date=12 September 2011 |accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref> Torner said he climbed the mountain to show African countries: "that we are able. But [also] protect us, give us a chance, don't stigmatize, don't isolate, don't hide us to the darkness room -- just open the way".<ref name=cnn/> [[Elizabeth May]], leader of the [[Green Party of Canada]] subsequently called him an international hero and compared him with [[Terry Fox]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://greenparty.ca/fr/node/3149 |title=Josephat Torner: A person with albinism - a Tanzanian Hero |publisher=[[Green Party of Canada]] |date=15 August 2011 |accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref> Torner has plans to climb [[Mount Everest]] in 2016.<ref name=lm/>
In 2012 Torner survived an attack.<ref>{{cite web|author=Flora Drury |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2922243/Hunted-like-animals-sold-families-75-000-Tanzania-s-albinos-hacked-apart-witchdoctors-believe-body-parts-bring-luck-sick-trade-fuelled-country-s-elite.html |title=Hunted down like animals and sold by their own families for £50,000: Tanzania's albinos hacked apart by witchdoctors who believe their body parts 'bring luck' in sick trade 'fuelled by the country's elite' |publisher=[[Daily Mail]] |date=26 January 2015 |accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref> He has criticized the Tanzanian government for not doing enough to educate others on misconceptions and superstitions regarding albinism.<ref>{{cite web|author=Dan Gilgoff |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2013/10/131011-albino-killings-witch-doctors-tanzania-superstition/ |title=As Tanzania's Albino Killings Continue, Unanswered Questions Raise Fears |publisher=[[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]] |date=10 October 2013 |accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref>
==Personal life== Torner is married and has three children.<ref name=cnn/>

6nam 9embilan | website = [http://krishnabalagita.org/] | current_members = | past_members = }} '''Krishna Balagita''', popular by his first name '''Krishna''' (born March 26, 1967 in [[Jakarta]]), is a Jakarta-born musician, arranger and composer. He achieves his popularity through Ada Band, a well-known band in Indonesia whose songs hit are Krishna's own creation. ==Career== Krishna started his professional career in music when he was 21. He joined some bands and performed in the café or hotel. Sometimes he would perform solo or played some pop music with a band. In other occasion he would play standard tunes with jazz quartet{{cite web|url=http://www.wartajazz.com/news/2009/08/06/devian-zikry-siap-tampil-di-asean-jazz-festival-2009/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110211004500/http://www.wartajazz.com/news/2009/08/06/devian-zikry-siap-tampil-di-asean-jazz-festival-2009/ |archivedate=February 11, 2011 |df= }} formation. He finally met Suriandika Satjadibrata and Baim in 1997. The three young men agreed to form a band called Ada Band. Seharusnya was the first album released in 1997 and the song with the same title got the success. Krishna successfully brought Ada Band{{cite news|url=http://musik.kapanlagi.com/berita/ditinggal-krishna-ada-band-krisis.html|title=Ditinggal Krishna, Ada Band Krisis|date=March 16, 2009|work=KapanLagi.com|accessdate=January 15, 2017}} to be one of the popular bands in the country. ''Masih'', ''Yang Terbaik Bagimu'', ''Haruskah Ku Mati'', and ''Manusia Bodoh'' are some of the hit. Ada Band on the other hand was able to feature [[Dave Koz]] to play 'Masih'. Meanwhile, he was not completely forgot jazz and released a solo album 'Sign of Eight' in 2002, his first jazz album.[http://www.kibordis.com/musisi.php?stateid=detailnews&idn=185Musisi.com] {{dead link|date=January 2017}} [[Indra Lesmana]], Gilang Ramadhan, [[Dewa Budjana]], [[Tohpati]]{{cite web|url=http://www.wartajazz.com/news/2003/01/14/nonton-tohpati-devian-imel-dan-krishna-balagita-di-jazz-odyssey-yuk/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110211004418/http://www.wartajazz.com/news/2003/01/14/nonton-tohpati-devian-imel-dan-krishna-balagita-di-jazz-odyssey-yuk/ |archivedate=February 11, 2011 |df= }} and Indro Hardjodikoro contributed to Krishna’s{{cite web|url=http://www.imimusik.com/detail-news-and-events.php?item%3D31 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713015840/http://www.imimusik.com/detail-news-and-events.php?item=31 |archivedate=July 13, 2011 |df= }} [[jazz]]{{cite web|url=http://www.equinoxdmd.com/krishnabalagita/default.htm |title=Krishna Balagita |website=Equinoxdmd.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-15}} project. [[Air Medal]] (6) |laterwork= }} '''Lance Peter Sijan''' (April 13, 1942 – January 22, 1968) was a [[United States]] [[United States Air Force|Air Force]] [[military officer|officer]] and fighter pilot. On March 4, 1976, he [[Posthumous recognition|posthumously]] received the [[Medal of Honor]], the United States' highest military award, for his selflessness and courage in the face of lethal danger.http://www.mishalov.com/Sijan.html ==Biography== Lance Peter Sijan, also known by his Serbian name '''Lazar Šijan''' ({{lang-sr-cyr|Лазар Шијан}}), was born to Sylvester and Jane Sijan on April 13, 1942, in [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]]. His father, who owned a restaurant, was an [[Serbs|ethnic Serb]], his parents emigrated from [[Serbia]] during [[World War I]]; his mother was an Irish-American. Lance was the eldest of three children. Sijan graduated from [[Bay View High School]] in 1960. Immediately after his graduation he attended the [[Naval Academy Preparatory School]] at the [[United States Naval Training Center, Bainbridge]], [[Maryland]]. After completion of the program, he gained an appointment to the [[United States Air Force Academy]] at [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]]."Naval Academy Preparatory School Reefpoints." MS. Naval Academy Preparatory School, Newport. He played on the academy's football team for three years, but quit the team in his final year to concentrate on his studies. Graduating with a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[Humanities]] in 1965,http://pow.usafalibrary.com/person.asp?id=35 he was awarded a [[second lieutenant]]'s commission and began [[Undergraduate Pilot Training]]. After its completion, he was assigned to the [[480th Tactical Fighter Squadron]], [[366th Fighter Wing]], stationed at [[Da Nang Air Base]], [[South Vietnam]]. He flew as a pilot and systems officer in an [[F-4 Phantom]].{{cite web|url=http://www.af.mil/history/person.asp?dec%3D%26pid%3D123006524 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090420172854/http://www.af.mil/history/person.asp?dec=&pid=123006524 |archivedate=2009-04-20 |df= }} ==Last mission== On the night of November 9, 1967, for his 52nd combat mission, Sijan and pilot Lt. Col. John Armstrong were tasked with a bombing mission to Ban Laboy ford in Laos. As they rolled in on their target to release their ordnance, their [[F-4 Phantom II|F-4C]] (AF Ser. No. 64-0751) was engulfed in a ball of fire due to the bomb fuses malfunctioning and causing a premature detonation on their release. Sijan managed to eject from the aircraft, and although likely rendered unconscious in the ejection, his parachute landed him on a rocky limestone [[karst]] ridge adjacent to the target. [[File:Lance Sijan.jpg|thumb|right|Sijan boarding a [[McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom II|F-4 Phantom II]]]] From the night of 9/10 November to the morning of 11 November, no electronic or radio signals were heard from either Sijan or Armstrong. However, early on the morning of 11 November, Sijan made radio contact with a [[Misty FAC]] F-100F aircraft that was flying over his crash site. For the duration of that day, the USAF launched a massive effort to locate his position, and 'soften up' the numerous enemy air defences in his area. At dusk, the [[search-and-rescue|SAR]] forces were finally able to position a [[CH-3|CH-3 Jolly Green Giant]] helicopter near Sijan's position. (During this overall rescue operation, over 20 aircraft were damaged by anti-aircraft fire, and many had to return to base. One A-1H aircraft was shot down, though its pilot was soon rescued by a SAR helicopter on station. Sijan, refusing to put other airmen in danger, insisted on trying to crawl to a jungle penetrator lowered by the helicopter, and he opposed the helicopter's Para-Jumper (PJ) coming down to find and rescue him. Sadly, the helicopter crew could not see him in the heavy jungle, and strangely, they did not deploy the PJ to find and rescue Sijan. After the Jolly Green hovered for 33 minutes, and upon hearing no further radio transmissions from Sijan, the on-scene SAR commander (flying in an [[A-1H]] Skyraider aircraft) suspected a trap, and thus ordered the Jolly Green and the entire SAR armada to withdraw. Search efforts continued the very next morning, but they were called off when no further radio contact was made with Sijan. He was then listed in a [[Missing In Action|MIA]] casualty status. During his violent ejection and very rough parachute landing on the karst ridge, Sijan had suffered a fractured skull, a mangled right hand, and a compound fracture of the left leg. He was without food, with very little water, and no survival kit; nevertheless, he evaded enemy forces for 46 days. During this entire period, Sijan was only able to move by sliding on his buttocks and back along the rocky limestone ridge and later along the jungle floor. After managing to move several thousand feet, Sijan crawled onto a truck road along the Ho Chi Minh Trail, where he was finally captured by the North Vietnamese on Christmas Day, 1967. Very emaciated and in poor health, Sijan was imprisoned in an NVA camp. Soon thereafter, he managed to incapacitate a guard and escape into the jungle, but was recaptured several hours later. Sijan was transported to a holding compound in [[Vinh]], [[North Vietnam]], where he was placed in the care of two other recently captured [[Prisoner of War|POW]]s, Air Force Major Robert R. Craner and Air Force Captain [[Guy Gruters]]. Although in terrific pain from his severe wounds and brutal beatings and torture from his captors, Sijan had not disclosed any information other than what the [[Geneva Convention]] guidelines allowed (name, date of birth, service, rank, and service number). Suffering terribly from exhaustion, malnutrition, and disease, he was soon transported to [[Hanoi]], under the attentive care of both Craner and Gruters. However, in his weakened state, he contracted pneumonia and died in [[Hỏa Lò Prison]] (better known as the "Hanoi Hilton") on January 22, 1968. First Lieutenant Sijan was promoted posthumously to [[Captain (United States O-3)|captain]] on June 13, 1968. His remains were repatriated on March 13, 1974, and were positively identified on April 22, 1974. He was buried with military honors in Arlington Park Cemetery in Milwaukee. His former cellmate USAF Colonel Craner recommended him for the Medal Of Honor, with supporting testimony provided by his other fellow cellmate, USAF Captain Gruters. Sijan received the Medal Of Honor posthumously in 1976, with his parents (Sylvester and Jane Sijan) receiving it on his behalf on March 4, 1976, from President [[Gerald R. Ford]].[http://www.aasdet355.com/sijan.html]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Military awards== Sijan's military decorations and awards include: {| |- | devices|number=0|type=oak|ribbon=Vietnam Campaign Medal ribbon with 60- clasp.svg|width=106}} |[[Vietnam Campaign Medal|Republic of Vietnam Campaign Medal with 1960- device]] |} ===Medal of Honor citation=== The [[President of the United States]] in the name of [[United States Congress|The Congress]] takes pride in presenting the MEDAL OF HONOR to '''SIJAN, LANCE P.''' Rank and organization: Captain, U.S. Air Force, 4th Allied POW Wing, Pilot of an F-4C aircraft. Place and Date: North Vietnam, 9 November 1967. Entered service at: Milwaukee, Wis. Born: 13 April 1942, Milwaukee, Wis. Citation: While on a flight over North Vietnam, Capt. Sijan ejected from his disabled aircraft and successfully evaded capture for more than 6 weeks. During this time, he was seriously injured and suffered from shock and extreme weight loss due to lack of food. After being captured by North Vietnamese soldiers, Capt. Sijan was taken to a holding point for subsequent transfer to a prisoner of war camp. In his emaciated and crippled condition, he overpowered 1 of his guards and crawled into the jungle, only to be recaptured after several hours. He was then transferred to another prison camp where he was kept in solitary confinement and interrogated at length. During interrogation, he was severely tortured; however, he did not divulge any information to his captors. Capt. Sijan lapsed into delirium and was placed in the care of another prisoner. During his intermittent periods of consciousness until his death, he never complained of his physical condition and, on several occasions, spoke of future escape attempts. Capt. Sijan's extraordinary heroism and intrepidity above and beyond the call of duty at the cost of his life are in keeping with the highest traditions of the U.S. Air Force and reflect great credit upon himself and the U.S. Armed Forces./S/[[Gerald Ford|GERALD R. FORD]] {{cite web|title=Sijan, Lance P.|url=http://www.homeofheroes.com/moh/citations_1960_vn/sijan_lance.html|publisher=Home of Heroes|accessdate=July 23, 2011}} ==Other honors== [[File:Lance Sijan park.jpg|right|thumb|300px|The Lance Sijan Memorial Site at Arlington Park Cemetery]] Sijan's heroism and courage brought him numerous honors. The United States Air Force created the [[Lance P. Sijan Award]], recognizing individuals who have demonstrated the highest qualities of leadership in their jobs and in their lives. It has become one of the [[United States Air Force|U.S. Air Force's]] most prestigious awards. Because Sijan was the first graduate of the [[United States Air Force Academy]] to receive the [[Medal of Honor]], a cadet dormitory, Sijan Hall, was named after him. The dormitory was dedicated on [[Memorial Day]], 1976. Sijan's high school in Milwaukee set up a scholarship in his honor, presented each year to the student who best exemplifies Lance Sijan's examples of leadership and courage. A nearby park, Sijan Playfield, is dedicated to him, and Milwaukee's Serbian community honors him with a memorial on the grounds of St. Sava Serbian Orthodox Cathedral. An [[F-4 Phantom II|F-4 Phantom]] jet fighter on display in front of the 440th Air Force Reserve at Milwaukee's [[General Mitchell International Airport|Mitchell Airport]] is painted using the color scheme of the one he flew. [https://web.archive.org/web/20070823070921/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4196/is_20060804/ai_n16661935] In June 2006, before the [[440th Airlift Wing]] was relocated to [[Pope Air Force Base|Pope AFB]] in [[North Carolina]], there were calls to move the [[F-4 Phantom II|F-4 Phantom]] jet fighter display from [[Mitchell International Airport]] to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial on the [[Lake Michigan]] lake front. However, the display was finally moved on February 28, 2017 to another more visible location at Mitchell International Airport. It will be re-dedicated at this location on May 26, 2017.{{cite web|title=Hometown hero: Warplane of Vietnam War hero Lance Sijan arrives at new home|url=http://fox6now.com/2017/02/28/hometown-hero-warplane-of-vietnam-war-hero-lance-sijan-arrives-at-new-home/|publisher=WITI Milwaukee|accessdate=February 28, 2017}} Sijan is a member of the [[DeMolay International]] Hall of Fame. [[Mountain Home Air Force Base|Mountain Home AFB]] in Idaho named Sijan St. in his honor. A major road at Elmendorf Air Force Base, Anchorage, Alaska, is also named for him. ==See also== {{Portal|Biography|United States Air Force}} *[[List of Medal of Honor recipients for the Vietnam War#S|List of Medal of Honor recipients for the Vietnam War]] *[[Lance P. Sijan Award]] ==References== {{Reflist}} *{{Cite web|accessdate=September 29, 2010 |url=http://www.virtualwall.org/ds/SijanLP01a.htm |title=The Virtual Wall |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202054708/http://virtualwall.org/ds/SijanLP01a.htm |archivedate=December 2, 2010 |df= }} *{{Cite web |accessdate=September 29, 2010 |url=http://www.af.mil/news/airman/0196/sijan.htm |title=June 1977 issue of ''Airman Magazine''|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19970407011020/http://www.af.mil/news/airman/0196/sijan.htm|archivedate=April 7, 1997}} *{{Cite web|accessdate=September 29, 2010 |url=http://www.afa.org/magazine/valor/1298valor.asp |title=December 1998 issue of ''Air Force Magazine'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080316234058/http://www.afa.org/magazine/valor/1298valor.asp |archivedate=March 16, 2008 }} *{{Cite web|accessdate=September 29, 2010 |url=http://www.af.mil/history/spotlight.asp?storyID=123009132 |title=U.S. Air Force 'Spotlight' Story |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080316053612/http://www.af.mil/history/spotlight.asp?storyID=123009132 |archivedate=March 16, 2008 }} *[[Into the Mouth of the Cat]], a book written by Malcolm McConnell, {{ISBN|9780393018998}} ==External links== *[http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/planeta.70.html:289626-Srbin-heroj-Amerike “Serb a hero in America”], Evening News, Marko Lopušina, 28 Jun 2010 *{{Cite web |accessdate=September 29, 2010 |url=http://www.rjsmith.com/Sijan-Shootdown.html |title=Map of the area where Sijan was shot down}} * {{Internet Archive short film|id=gov.dod.dimoc.613468|name=Into the Mouth of the Cat - the Lance P. {{Infobox writer | name = Leona Florentino | image = Leona Florentino.jpg | alt = A statue of a sitting woman | caption = Statue of Leona Florentino at Calle Crisologo viewed at night. | pseudonym = | birth_name = Leona Josefa Florentina<ref name="baptism">{{cite web |url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/3:1:3QS7-99ZK-RH4P |title=Film # 007487537 Image Film # 007487537; ark:/61903/3:1:3QS7-99ZK-RH4P — FamilySearch.org |accessdate=27 September 2016}}</ref> | birth_date = {{Birth date|1849|4|19|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Vigan]], [[Ilocos Sur]], [[Captaincy General of the Philippines]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1884|10|4|1849|4|19|df=y}} | death_place = [[Vigan]], [[Ilocos Sur]], [[Captaincy General of the Philippines]] | occupation = Novelist, Political Writer, and Journalist | language = Spanish, Ilocano | nationality = Filipino | ethnicity = | spouse = Elias de los Reyes (1863–1884, until her death) | children = [[Isabelo de los Reyes]], 4 unnamed }} '''Leona Florentino''' (born '''Leona Josefa Florentina''',<ref name="baptism"/> 19 April 1849 - 4 October 1884) was a Filipino poet in the [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Ilokano language|Ilocano]] languages. She is considered as the "mother of Philippine women's literature" and the "bridge from oral to literary tradition".<ref name=Firefly>[http://www.filippiinit-seura.fi/firefly.html The History of Filipino Women's Writings], an article from Firefly - Filipino Short Stories (Tulikärpänen - filippiiniläisiä novelleja), 2001 / 2007</ref>
Born to a wealthy and prominent family in [[Vigan]], [[Ilocos Sur]], Florentino began to write her first verses in Ilocano at a young age. Despite her potential, she was not allowed to receive a university education because of her gender. Florentino was instead tutored by her mother, and then a series of private teachers. An educated Ilocano priest taught her advanced Spanish and encouraged her to develop her voice in poetry.<ref name=Firefly/>
Florentino married a politician named Elias de los Reyes at the age of 14. They had five children together. Their son [[Isabelo de los Reyes]] later became a Filipino writer, activist and senator. Due to the feminist nature of her writings, Florentino was shunned by her husband and son; she lived alone in exile and separately from her family.<ref name=Firefly/> She died at the age of 35.<ref name=Firefly/>
==Works== Her lyrical poetry in Spanish, and especially that in Ilocano, gained attention in various international forums in [[Spain]], [[Paris]] and [[St. Louis, Missouri]]. Her literary contributions - particularly 22 preserved poems - were recognized when she was included in the ''Encyclopedia Internationale des Oeuvres des Femmes'' (International Encyclopedia of Women’s Works) in 1889. She is believed to be the first Filipina to receive this international recognition, an homage that occurred after her death at a young age.<ref name=Firefly/>

:''This page refers to the performer and animal trainer born in 1947. For his son see [[Martin Lacey, Jr.]]
<!-- Commented out because image was deleted: [[File:MartinLacey2.jpg|thumb|right|350px|Circus advertisement featuring Martin Lacey in the 1970s.]] -->
'''Martin Lacey''' (born 1947) is a circus ringmaster, company director and trainer of wild animals. He trained most of the tigers that were used in the [[Esso]] television advertisements in the 1970s<ref>http://www.newshound.org.uk/April%202006.htm</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2001/feb/07/martinwainwright | work=The Guardian | location=London | title='Nip' from tiger puts trainer in hospital | first=Martin | last=Wainwright | date=2001-02-07 | accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref>
==Professional life== He has been breeding and training animals including lions, tigers and elephants for over forty years. He is a Government Registered Wild Animal Trainer.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/kent/content/articles/2007/09/18/circus_feature.shtml</ref>
In his heyday he appeared in UK television variety shows and was known as the “King Of The Cage”<ref>http://www.deabirkett.com/pages/journalism_film/film/the_show_must_go_on.htm</ref> and "the Man Fear Forgot".<ref>http://images.google.co.uk/imgres?imgurl=http://manchesterhistory.net/bellevue/circus/lion.jpg&imgrefurl=http://manchesterhistory.net/bellevue/circus.html&usg=__POJXvuahPi6QKQB8PsodfhLSQGo=&h=285&w=196&sz=13&hl=en&start=77&tbnid=r6gKqJY_HBAuLM:&tbnh=115&tbnw=79&prev=/images%3Fq%3D%2522martin%2Blacey%2522%26gbv%3D2%26ndsp%3D20%26hl%3Den%26sa%3DN%26start%3D60</ref> He provided most of the tigers used in the [[Esso]] oil television advertisements up until the 1970s.<ref>[[Keal Cotes]]</ref> However, changes in public attitudes to performing animals mean that he has faced criticism in recent years.
==Companies== He is the owner of the [[Great British Circus]] company that, unusually for the UK, organises circuses with live wild animals including tigers, camels and elephants. He is also a director of Linctrek Ltd, a company which provides trained animals for films, television, commercials and zoos.<ref>http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/homepage/Protest-outiside-North-Somerset-zoo-circus-breeding-claims/article-1438604-detail/article.html</ref>
==Use of wild animals== His use of wild animals has attracted considerable criticism and protests.<ref>http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/news/4511837.Animal_rights_protest_is_planned_outside_circus_ten</ref><ref>http://www.veggies.org.uk/event.php?ref=239</ref><ref>http://www.geocities.com/wmids_animalaction/great-british-circus.html </ref> However, he defends his company's approach as follows: "The Circus takes veterinary advice from world-respected experts, not from campaign groups who too often seek to excite public sympathy in their quest for donations and support.".<ref>http://www.greatbritishcircus.co.uk/</ref>
==BBC investigation into links with Noah’s Ark Zoo Farm== In October 2009 it was revealed by the [[BBC]] and the [[Captive Animals Protection Society]]<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.captiveanimals.org/news/2009/noah.html |title=CAPS expose zoo breeding tigers for circus owner |date=October 2009 |publisher=The Captive Animals' Protection Society |accessdate=2009-10-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091028013953/http://www.captiveanimals.org/news/2009/noah.html |archivedate=2009-10-28 |df= }} </ref> that many of the animals at [[Noah's Ark Zoo Farm]] near Bristol, including [[tiger]]s and [[camel]]s are owned by Lacey’s [[Great British Circus]] company, and the owners had been keeping the arrangement secret from visitors and from the [[British and Irish Association of Zoos and Aquariums]] (BIAZA).<ref> {{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1221493/Zoo-skinned-dead-tiger-Tira-stored-head-freezer.html |title=Zoo skinned dead tiger Tira and stored her head in freezer |work=Mail Online |publisher=Associated Newspapers Ltd |date=19 October 2009 |accessdate=2009-10-19 |last=Daily Mail Reporter }} </ref> The zoo denied the claims, stating "We do not hold Circus Tigers here at the Zoo. Our tigers come from Linctrek Ltd., based in North West England, and do not belong to the Great British Circus, contrary to claims made".<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.noahsarkzoofarm.co.uk/pages/visiting/visiting.php |title=Recent Press Coverage |publisher=Noah's Ark Zoo Farm |accessdate=2009-10-19 }} </ref>
==Personal life== He lives at [[Keal Cotes]] in Lincolnshire.<ref>http://bigcatescapesmaulings.blogspot.com/2005_12_01_archive.html</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2001/feb/07/martinwainwright | work=The Guardian | location=London | title='Nip' from tiger puts trainer in hospital | first=Martin | last=Wainwright | date=2001-02-07 | accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref> His wife Susan, also a circus performer and animal trainer, is now retired.<ref>[[:de:Martin Lacey jr]]</ref> He has four sons, Edward Lacey, Alex Lacey and [[Martin Lacey, Jr.]] who are animal trainers,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.q-easy.co.uk/zoo/archive.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-10-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090929090447/http://www.q-easy.co.uk/zoo/archive.htm |archivedate=2009-09-29 |df= }}</ref> and Richard, who does not work in the circus industry. Since he retired from the big top, Martin Lacey is active as circus consultant for Billi Smiles circus, a new circus in its first year of touring.<ref>http://www.billismilescircus.com/</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== * http://www.greatbritishcircus.co.uk/
{{Authority control}}
